markdownRemark.html:
Score: 92.5

missoulian.com  (WEB - en-US)

A website for the Missoulian, a newspaper based in Missoula, Montana, that dates to the post-Civil War era.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The website is owned by Lee Enterprises, a publicly traded, Davenport, Iowa-based company that owns more than 40 daily newspapers, including The St. Louis Post-Dispatch. Lee Enterprises’ newspapers generate revenue from advertising and subscriptions to their printed and digital editions.

Missoulian.com runs advertising and uses a meter system, charging readers after they spend a certain amount of time on the site. “Homepages and popular sections listing headlines, are always free,” the site states.

Content

Missoulian.com reports on local politics, government, crime, education, and other issues relating to Missoula and the state. Stories on the homepage have included interviews with candidates for the U.S. House of Representatives and other offices, a report on an energy company’s plans to move a transmission line because of flooding concerns, and an account of a dispute between the federal government and the Crow Indian tribe over alleged mismanagement of tribal funds.

The site has standalone pages dedicated to news about the University of Montana and to outdoor activities. It also publishes state, national, and international news from other Lee Enterprises publications and The Associated Press.

Subscribers can access an e-edition of the Missoulian’s printed newspaper on the site.

Credibility

Articles on the site are generally well-sourced and measured. Headlines reflect the content of stories. Missoulian.com publishes corrections at the bottom of stories, explaining how the error was fixed.

Missoulian.com posts opinion content -- including editorials, columns, and letters to the editor -- in a separate section.

Transparency

The site’s Contact Us page lists about two dozen members of the newsroom staff, including editors, photographers, and reporters. The site also shares a main phone number and email addresses for readers to submit news tips, letters to the editor, events, and obituaries. Articles include the name of the writer and contact information.

The website does not have an About Us page, and NewsGuard could not find information on the site, aside from on its Terms of Use and Privacy Policy pages, identifying Lee Enterprises as its owner. When asked about this, Missoulian general manager Matt Gibson said in an email, “There’s no specific reason for our choice.”

Advertisements are distinguishable from news content.

History

The Missoulian began in 1870 as the Missoula and Cedar Creek Pioneer. Lee Enterprises has owned the newspaper since 1959. In 2011, The Missoulian covered sexual assault reports at Missoula’s University of Montana that sparked a joint investigation by the U.S. Department of Justice and Department of Education.

The Missoulian.com domain name was first registered in 1995.

Written by:
Sam Howard

Edited by:
Peggy Ackermann Eric Effron
